tossups.question: An essay by Anna Lardo in The Ludic Self in Seventeenth-Century English Literature uses this concept to analyze the play Hamlet. In the book Violent Origins, this concept is illustrated by a subject hearing a model say "imitate me," leading to a contest in which the subject and model form a rivalry over the same object. A theory of desire using the "mimetic" form of this concept is presented in the book Things Hidden Since the Foundation of the World. The book that introduced this idea argues that a person receiving both a "primary" and "secondary" injunction is responsible for this so-called "pattern of communication." This concept is responsible for causing people to believe in a "delusional world" according to the book Steps to an Ecology of Mind. According to Gregory Bateson, schizophrenia is a result of, for 10 points, what cybernetics concept in which an individual receives two contrasting messages?

Typical multigrid methods tend to work poorly when solving the "indefinite" form of this equation. Arnold Sommerfeld developed a set of boundary conditions for which solutions of this equation are considered “radiating.” By substituting a generalized solution into this time-independent equation, ignoring the imaginary part, and taking the limit as frequency becomes infinite, one can derive the eikonal equation. This equation can be rewritten in a special form by expanding one operator into longitudinal and transverse components and expressing the solution in terms of a slowly-varying complex envelope. That form of this equation, which is used to describe Gaussian beams and Fresnel diffraction, is its "paraxial" form. Fourier transforming the wave equation into frequency space yields, for 10 points, what differential equation, which states that the Laplacian of phi plus k-squared phi equals zero?

This album’s liner notes include Nora Kelly's assertion that it depicts “ancient tales” of “beauty and danger” where “silence cloaks a lurking dagger.” A track on this album opens with eight repetitions of two staccato G alt7 [alt-7] chords resolving to a C major 7 sharp 5 chord, before skipping to free-form improv and eschewing any traditional melody. The first track on this album opens with the piano vamping on a D suspended 7 chord for 4 bars, has a modal 32-bar form consisting almost entirely of suspended chords, and was originally written as a jingle for Fabergé cosmetics. This album's five tracks include “Little One” and “Survival of the Fittest.” Its song “Eye of the Hurricane” was later re-performed by its composer's fusion group, The Headhunters. “Dolphin Dance” is one of the tracks that depicts the “splendor of a sea-going vessel” on, for 10 points, what 1965 concept album by Herbie Hancock?

In a case named for this man, a group of retired officers filed the “Green Brief.” He was the defendant of the case in which the dissenting opinion accused the majority of “responding to a faddish slogan of the cognoscenti” by allowing people to “take the bait” and not succeed in the “cauldron of competition.” The court cases named after this man featured an amicus brief about the competitiveness of American workers filed by General Motors, and largely revolved around a speech this man gave about “seven myths,” including the myth that “race doesn’t matter” and that “self-segregation” cannot be combatted in defending his institution’s policy of “maintaining a critical mass”. However, the Court did rule that his use of a points-based admission policy that disfavored Jennifer Gratz was unconstitutional. For 10 points, identify this University of Michigan president who was the defendant in two Bush-era affirmative action cases.

This book describes how a vengeful gentleman once locked his wife in a room with a cabinet full of bones and forced her to drink from a skull that had its eye sockets plugged with silver. This text’s characters include Roncex, who screams after sitting on some dung in an outhouse, causing the servant La Mothe to think she is being "ravished." In this book, a woman punishes her impious son by doing the bed trick on him and getting pregnant, then later having him unwittingly marry the daughter born from that night many years later. This book, which was originally titled Tales of Fortunate Lovers, is largely narrated by a group in the Abbey of Our Lady who wait for a bridge to be built. Francois Rabelais so admired this book's author that he dedicated the third book of Gargantua and Pantagruel to her. For 10 points, name this collection of 72 bawdy tales by Marguerite de Navarre.
tossups.answer: Heptameron [or Tales of Fortunate Lovers before “Tales”]

tossups.question: A definition of these computational constructs given by John Power, making use of Lawvere Theory, inspired the work of Gordon Plotkin, who showed that "computational effects" determine the identity of these things. These programming constructs are given the properties of "enrichment" and "finitariness" in a paper by Luth and Ghani that defines their composition using coproducts. In the 1991 paper by Eugenio Moggi that first applied these things to computer science, they are specified using Kleisli triples. These constructs can be used to implement continuation passing style since they often employ the keyword "maybe" to separate stateful code from code that lacks side effects. In Haskell, they are often used to handle input and output. For 10 points, name these units from functional programming that allow for the chaining of operations, and which take their name from category theory.

A book by this author analyzes a 19th-century hairdresser who wrote the poem “Francouneto,” in which a woman is suspected of being a sorceress after her suitors lose their limbs while courting her. Another of this historian’s books is about Thomas Platter, a foundling who becomes a thief and then a scholar after a chance conversation. Yet a third book by this author discusses the creation of "folklore kingdoms" symbolized by a sheep, partridge, and cockerel within a town taken over by artisans. This author of Jasmin's Witch and The Beggar and the Professor analyzed the formation of reynages, or folk gatherings, as a mentalite in The Carnival of the Romans. Another of his books has been translated using the phrase "the promised land of error," and uses the Fournier Registry to reconstruct the life of Cathars. The Annales school was once led by, for 10 points, what historian and author of Montaillou?

In the third movement of George Crumb’s Echoes of Time and the River, this instrument spells out Crumb’s name in Morse code. It plays a repeated melodic fragment consisting of a leap down a minor ninth from B-flat to A, followed by G-sharp, A, leap up to B-flat, leap down to A, at the outset of an orchestral work derived from the ballet Cave of the Heart. Six bars into the “Polka” from Dmitri Shostakovich’s The Golden Age, this instrument introduces the movement's main melody. Flutes, oboes, clarinets, piano, strings, and this instrument begin rapid, constant 16th note figuration in the fourth bar of the overture to Porgy and Bess. It joins a clarinet, strings, and two pianos in a movement that quotes the folk songs “Ah! Vous dirai-je, maman” and “Au clair de la lune,” in which it parodies its own part from the Danse macabre. “Fossils,” from Carnival of the Animals, features, for 10 points, what percussion instrument Camille Saint-Saens used to represent rattling bones?
tossups.answer: xylophone [do not accept or prompt on “marimba” or “glockenspiel” or any other mallet/keyboard percussion instrument]
tossups.answer_formatted: xylophone [do not accept or prompt on "marimba" or "glockenspiel" or "any other mallet/keyboard percussion instrument"]

tossups.question: Paul Friedlander identified a "polyphonic" form of this concept in a work in which the "very stupid question" is asked, "can there be no such thing as an erroneous action?" Jean-Paul once proposed that a new punctuation mark in addition to the question and exclamation be used to indicate this concept. Hegel believed that this concept and its formulator's maieutics were key to allowing a philosopher to "put forth their principles" even though Hegel wrote that this concept is “vanity” in his Phenomenology of Spirit. Another thinker asserted that just like "there is no true science without doubt", there is "no genuinely human life" without this concept in a text that claims Aristophanes' portrayal of this concept’s user is realistic since a philosopher is full of this concept, which is called "infinite absolute negativity". A dissertation by Kierkegaard that makes continual reference to Socrates is about Socrates’s use of, for 10 points, what concept?

The text of a novel centering on these objects is supposedly authored by Voragine, a hack writer and "hagiographer" who befriends the narrator, a man who loves telling "hyperbolics" throughout the book. A "notorious" set of these objects supposedly belonging to Borges, Montaigne, Petrarch, Virginia Woolf, and Plato is sold by the "Best Auctioneer in the World," Gustavo "Highway" Sanchez, in that Valeria Luiselli novel about the "story" of some of these objects. In another novel, an elderly man named Mr. Hamilton tells a racist story in which he could only distinguish people of the Congo by these things. After discovering a set of these objects that are not real, an adolescent girl tries to move to her grandmother's house and finds that Ryan Topps, Clara Bowden's ex-boyfriend, has become a Jehovah's Witness. For 10 points, name these objects, which title a novel about Archie Jones, written by Zadie Smith.
tossups.answer: teeth [accept White Teeth or The Story of My Teeth]
tossups.answer_formatted: teeth [accept White Teeth or The Story of My Teeth]

tossups.question: This work's last section prognosticates that “Grandstands will disappear because no one will be there to occupy them” and denounces the sports of boxing and wrestling as savage behaviors. A section of this text about the “means of transportation” declares that “no person” has the “authority to own a means of transportation for the purpose of renting it,” since it means controlling the needs of others. The author of this book recast some of its ideas into a short parable about an astronaut that commits suicide, which can be found in his collection Escape To Hell. This book argues for the abolition of money, and the first of its three volumes, The Solution of the Problem of Democracy, appeared in 1975 and outlines its formulator's “Third International Theory.” The Great Socialist People's Jamahiriya state was partly based on this book, written by its author after deposing King Idris I. For 10 points, name this work of political thought by Muammar Qaddafi.

James Clauss claims that a passage about this man’s war with his brother was inserted into a poem to commentate on the conflict between members of the Flavian Dynasty. Pliny the Elder claims that a descendant of this ruler named Saulaces built a palace after he conquered King Sesostris. In one account, this man betroths his daughter to an Albanian prince named Styrus. This man’s brother was deposed shortly after he imprisoned Medus. A youth visits the kingdom of this son of Helios by using an animal that his mother Nephele had sent for him so that he could escape Ino. An epic poem by Valerius Flaccus includes a lengthy episode in which this man wages war against his brother Perses. This father of Chalciope orders that a foreigner use fire-breathing bulls to plough a field and sow it with dragon’s teeth. For 10 points, name this king of Colchis who once owned the Golden Fleece.

John Sfakianakis once remarked that the only store missing in this city was a “Filene's Basement” in an article discussing the 30-billion-dollar project of adding a five-story megamall to it. A 2014 book by Ziauddin Sardar about the eventual destruction of this city calls it a “reconfigured utopia” since modernity has made this city “mundane.” The ALJREIC group’s 3.1-billion-dollar investment plan in this city includes building its massive Anjum Hotel. Its Raffles Palace Hotel is popular since it is near the tourist sites of the Mountain of Light and a mountain that contains the “Cave of the Bull.” In order to construct the world's second-most-costly building here, the Ajyad Fortress was destroyed; that building contains the world's largest clock face and is part of the Abraj Al Bait Towers. A highway from Jeddah is the main way to enter, for 10 points, what birthplace of the prophet Muhammad, the most popular Islamic tourist destination?

In a meditation, a character wishes that "every new book shall be a labyrinth" of these things from which a person shall "vainly try to extricate himself." That meditation opens by claiming the desultory manner of these things can be found in the "satires and epistles of the excellent Horace," and asserts that Horace is merely a collection of these things. The work in which these things appear is described as "progressive" by its narrator because these things supposedly represent the "soul of reading." Christoph Henke claims that the novel in which these things appear exhibits "self-reflexivity," since the recounting of these things prevents the story of the king of Bohemia and his seven Castles from ever being recited. The text of Walter's encyclopedia, and the story of Hafen Slawkenbergius are examples of, for 10 points, what passages in Tristram Shandy that occupy the narrative so much that Tristram's birth isn't described until Book III?
tossups.answer: digressions in the work of Laurence Sterne [accept stories or interpolated passages from Tristram Shandy because eventually the material described is not a term of art]
tossups.answer_formatted: digressions in the work of Laurence Sterne [accept stories or interpolated passages from Tristram Shandy because eventually the material described is not a term of art]
acceptable: digressions in the work of Laurence Sterne
digressions in the work of Laurence Sterne
interpolated passages from Tristram Shandy because eventually the material described is not a term of art

tossups.question: Two proteins found in this organism share a large degree of homology within their C-termini--those regions are called "combined repetitive oligopeptides." In October 2016, the FDA approved the drug bezlotoxumab to treat infections by this pathogen. This organism's virulence is primarily based on two glucosyltransferase proteins which inactivate Rac, Rho, and other small GTPases; those proteins are its namesake A and B toxins. The drug fidaxomicin treats infections by this organism, which are more commonly treated with orally-administered vancomycin or metronidazole. Because this opportunistic pathogen infects patients with a disrupted microbiome, it can be treated using a fecal transplant to restore normal gut flora. For 10 points, name this spore-forming and colon-infecting bacterium, the leading cause of antibiotic-associated diarrhea.
tossups.answer: Clostridium difficile [do not accept or prompt on partial answers]
tossups.answer_formatted: Clostridium difficile [do not accept or prompt on "partial answers"]

tossups.question: In a dendrological analysis, the critic Robert Koch claims that this section of a larger work depicts a “dragon palm” tree, reflecting its creator's interest in herbal texts. Anna Boczkowska argues that its artist was inspired by alchemy, since this panel's center depicts a structure with spiky appendages that make the structure resemble Cancer the Crab, and because the structure rests on a dark mound of crystals, pearls, and other gems. A pit of “primeval ooze” in the lower right of this section of a larger work contains a duck-billed creature reading a scholarly text while dressed in monk's garb, as well as an aqueous unicorn. Phyllis Lehman argues that Cyriacus d'Acona's account of his journey to the Holy Land inspired its depiction of a white and gray giraffe. A monumental pink fountain behind Adam and Eve is at the center of, for 10 points, what panel from Hieronymus Bosch's The Garden of Earthly Delights?
tossups.answer: The Paradise panel from The Garden of Earthly Delights [or the Garden of Eden panel from The Garden of Earthly Delights; accept the Left panel from The Garden of Earthly Delights. do not accept or prompt on "The Garden of Earthly Delights"]
tossups.answer_formatted: The Paradise panel from The Garden of Earthly Delights [or the Garden of Eden panel from The Garden of Earthly Delights; accept the Left panel from The Garden of Earthly Delights. do not or or prompt on "The Garden of Earthly Delights]
acceptable: The Paradise panel from The Garden of Earthly Delights
Paradise panel from The Garden of Earthly Delights
Garden of Eden panel from The Garden of Earthly Delights
Left panel from The Garden of Earthly Delights. do not
or prompt on "The Garden of Earthly Delights

tossups.question: This kind of reaction is used to convert the compounds DMPA and camphorquinone into their active form. It's not a decarboxylation, but one reaction of this type used to convert nitrite esters to delta-nitrosoalcohols is named for Derek Barton. In another reaction of this type, a compound with two alkenes separated by a single quaternary carbon rearranges to form a vinyl-substituted cyclopropane--that reaction is the di-pi-methane rearrangement. Carbonyls can be cleaved using this type of reaction in both type I and type II Norrish reactions. An example of these reactions useful in microfabrication of semiconductor devices is the Wolff rearrangement. An electrocyclic ring closure of this type proceeds in a conrotatory fashion according to the Woodward-Hoffmann rules. Thermal reactions are contrasted with, for 10 points, what class of reactions which are denoted using the letters "h nu" over the reaction arrow?
tossups.answer: photochemical reactions [accept answers indicating the reaction is catalyzed by light; accept photolysis or pretty much anything with the prefix photo-; prompt on answers indicating that the reaction involves free radicals]
tossups.answer_formatted: photochemical reactions [accept answers indicating the reaction is catalyzed by light; accept photolysis or pretty much anything with the prefix photo-; prompt on answers indicating that the reaction involves free radicals]
acceptable: answers indicating the reaction is catalyzed by light
pretty much anything with the prefix photo-
promptable: answers indicating that the reaction involves free radicals

tossups.question: Prior to a battle named for this city, the losing commander arrested all the sons of his former advisor, drained their blood into two bowls, and mixed it with wine as a pre-battle drink. A legend says this city was saved from attack when a priest-king sent a pack of field mice to gnaw on the bowstrings and shield-straps of Sennacherib’s army. Nectanebo II was defeated here in 343 BC by the Theban general Lacrates in a victory for Artaxerxes III. At an earlier battle here, Polycrates of Samos sent forty triremes to aid the victors, who benefited from the navigation of the traitor Phanes of Helicarnassus. According to Polyaenus, the invaders pinned cats to their shields because opposing archers would not attack them at another battle here in which Psamtik III was defeated by Cambyses II, giving the throne to the Persians. For 10 points, name this ancient city on the eastern Nile delta, called the “stronghold of Egypt.”
tossups.answer: Pelusium [or Pelousion, or Sa’inu or Per-Amon]

tossups.question: A design by the Bjarke Ingels Group proposes that this city's co-generation power plant be surrounded by a geodesic dome of many-colored glass for the purposes of tourism. Every night at 10pm, the university students in this city's district of Flogsta will spontaneously scream into the night. Etienne de Bonneuil designed the massive Gothic cathedral of this city, which is where the inventor of the modern index card is buried. After a mad king killed five nobles during the Sture Murders, most of the bodies were interred in this city. The Celsius Scale was developed at its university, which contains a building honoring native son Dag Hammarskjold. A text by Adam of Bremen describes how a building in this city was inlaid with gold and contains statues depicting Wotan and Frikko. For 10 points, name this city which once contained a massive temple devoted to Norse gods.

A villanelle by this writer describes its subject having “blown on a blue horn, full of sound and fury / but signifying, o signifying magnificently / the boredom, and the horror, and the glory.” Another poem by this author describes “the arches and entrances” of “seven houses” that have “learned to face one another” and “mastered the lesson of remaining closed.” That poem by this man mentions three clouds that are “not public like mountains' but private like companions'.” This author wrote poems about Robert Boardman Vaughan and a painting by “Patient B.” He imagined the title figures rediscovering “the face of the boy as he practices tying his father’s tie” in a poem centering on people who “learn to close softly, the doors to rooms they will not be coming back to.” For 10 points, name this New Formalist author of “Men at Forty,” who won the 1980 Pulitzer Prize for his Selected Poems.

bonuses.leadin: One book within this framework, Madame Bovary’s Ovaries, argues that Othello’s importance was not his skin color, but the fact he was “all about the sperm.” For 10 points each:
answers: literary Darwinism [prompt on biopoetics; prompt on evolutionary studies or evolutionary criticism; accept answers indicating it is the use of Charles Darwin’s thought to study literature]
The Experimental Novel [or Le Roman Experimental]
On the Origin of Species [or On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection, or the Preservation of Favoured Races in the Struggle for Life]
parts: Name this field of study started by Joseph Carroll, which analyzes novels and plays to find aspects of imagination and symbolic thought in the human psyche that reflect biological principles.

A translation of Charles Darwin by Clemence Royer influenced the ideas found in this book by Emile Zola, which incorporates the ideas of scientist Claude Bernard to propose a theory of naturalist literature.

Brian Boyd asks “why do we not prefer information that is true” in a work of evolutionary criticism that puns on the title of this 1859 book by Charles Darwin, which introduced the theory of evolution by natural selection.
answers_formatted: literary Darwinism [prompt on biopoetics; prompt on evolutionary studies or evolutionary criticism; accept answers indicating it is the use of Charles Darwin’s thought to study literature]
On the Origin of Species [or On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection, or the Preservation of Favoured Races in the Struggle for Life]
acceptable: answers indicating it is the use of Charles Darwin’s thought to study literature
On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection,
Preservation of Favoured Races in the Struggle for Life

bonuses.leadin: The usage of these devices is referred to as "biolistic transformation." For 10 points each:
answers: Bacillus thuringiensis [or Bt; do not accept or prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name these devices which use a helium propellant to deliver DNA particles coated in gold or tungsten to cells. They're commonly used to accomplish transformation in plants.

A common application of gene guns in industry is to transform plant cells with the Cyt and Cry toxins derived from this organism. Those toxins form pores in the midgut epithelial cells of many small invertebrates.
Another common example of genetic transformation of plant cells is the creation of this specialized crop, which contains genes needed to biosynthesize beta-carotene.
answers_formatted: Bacillus thuringiensis [or Bt; do not accept or prompt on "partial answers"]

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the political career of Louis Blanc, for 10 points.
answers: National Workshops [or Ateliers Nationaux, prompt on social workshops]
parts: In the provisional government of the French Second Republic, Blanc issued a motion which established these relief agencies, and Emile Thomas was appointed as their supervisor. The closure of these organizations led to the June Days Uprising.

Blanc was named president of this commission, created by the provisional government to study programs of social reform. It passed a directive converting the Clichy debtors’ prison into a government workhouse.

After returning from exile, Blanc led a leftist group together with Georges Clemenceau and this man, who walked the beaches in San Sebastián after using the Armand-Barbés hot air balloon to make his slapstick escape from the Paris Commune.
answers_formatted: National Workshops [or Ateliers Nationaux, prompt on social workshops]
acceptable: Ateliers Nationaux, prompt on social workshops

bonuses.leadin: This man and Clay Felkner collaborated to found the New York magazine, and employed Tom Wolfe, Nora Ephron, and others to write for it. For 10 points each:
answers: I Love NY [or I heart NY]
New Wave of Design [or Swiss Punk Typography]
parts: Name this man better known as a graphic designer. This member of Pushpin Studio created the Babyteeth typeface, which he used in a poster showing Bob Dylan with psychedelic hair.
Glaser is probably best known as the designer of this image, which was inspired by Robert Indiana's LOVE sculptures. A general description of this logo is acceptable.

Wolfgang Weingart, a contemporary of Glaser who was also influenced by pop art in his design, is best-known for pioneering this style of design that avoids using right angles and fixed sizes. It was started at the Basel school.

bonuses.leadin: The founder of this discipline proposed that disorganized, neutral, and organized complexes are the three types of neutral systems. For 10 points each:
answers: Ernst Haeckel [or Ernst Heinrich Philipp August Haeckel]
parts: Name this universal science that would have systematized all disciplines, lifeforms, and non-living things according to a set of principles of organization. It was developed by Alexander Bogdanov.

Tektology was first mentioned by this German scientist and philosopher who once remarked that "ontogeny recapitulated phylogeny." His book The Riddle of the Universe introduced the term "world-riddle."
Bogdanov's ideas were suppressed by this other philosopher, who claimed that "Imperialism" is the highest stage of capitalism. He also wrote the April Theses.

bonuses.leadin: One of these structures is named after the Japanese word for chopsticks, Hashihaka, due to its resemblance to those utensils, and is thought to contain the body of the mythical queen Pimiko. For 10 points each:
answers: horse-riders [or horse-riders theory or kiba minzoku setsu]
parts: Name these keyhole-shaped megalithic tombs in Japan. The era lasting from roughly the 3rd century to the 6th century is named for them.

The largest kofun in Japan is thought to house the body of Emperor Nintoku, and can be found in what is this modern-day city. Toyotomi Hideyoshi built its green-roofed castle during the Sengoku period.

In 1948, Egami Namio presented a theory holding that the distinctive style of the kofun era was due to these invaders from Mimana, a 1st- or 2nd-century Korean state. The theory is often named for these warriors.

bonuses.leadin: This work was written to argue against the idea that a certain figure “bore his pain in silence” due to the nobility of his soul. For 10 points each:
answers: Laocoon: An Essay on the Limits of Painting and Poetry
parts: Name this essay, which maintains that “succession in time” is the “province of the poet,” whereas “co-existence in space is that of the artist.” It was written to criticize the ideas of Johann Winckelmann.
The essay Laocoon is named for a sculpture depicting Laocoon and his sons being strangled by these animals.

This critic described the Laocoon group as the perfect model of “symmetry” in his Observations on the Laocoon. “What did the artist set out to do?” is one of this author’s “three questions” for constructive criticism.
answers_formatted: Laocoon: An Essay on the Limits of Painting and Poetry
acceptable: Laocoon: An Essay on the Limits of Painting and Poetry
Laocoon: An Essay on the Limits of Painting and Poetry

bonuses.leadin: Erik O. Wright used his writings on this movement to propose the concept of “interstitial revolution,” the idea that societies can dramatically change by increasing the number of people in social spaces. For 10 points each:
answers: analytical Marxism [or analytic Marxism; accept word forms; accept the September Group]
parts: Name this movement that sought to use methods from the hard sciences to support theories of exploitation and alienation first identified by a 19th-century philosopher. It was introduced in a “defense” by Gerald Cohen.

This analytic Marxist philosopher wrote Making Sense of Marx. This Norwegian’s other books include Sour Grapes, a book about the origins of irrational belief in people, which follows up on his Ulysses and the Sirens.

Cohen’s interpretation of Marx makes use of the work of this economist’s theory of “technological determinism,” the idea that a society’s technology dictates its progress. This man also wrote The Theory of the Leisure Class.
answers_formatted: analytical Marxism [or analytic Marxism; accept word forms; accept the September Group]

bonuses.leadin: The speaker compares the title objects of this poem to a torch that will take him to the "sightless realm where darkness is awake upon the dark." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this poem, which is named after flowers that the speaker compares to "Pluto's dark-blue daze, black lamps from the halls of Dis, burning dark blue, giving off darkness, blue darkness."
“Bavarian Gentians” is one of the many poems by this novelist, whose books include The Plumed Serpent.

This other poet opined "back on the valley freeway at the first motel / they forget both noble Navajo and DHL" in a poem commemorating the 50th anniversary of the death of D. H. Lawrence, "The Call of Nature." In another of his poems, the speaker imagines offering "some kumquats" to John Keats.

bonuses.leadin: The spacing between spectral lines in the P and R branches is equal to two times this quantity. For 10 points each:
answers: J squared, times J plus one squared [accept J to the fourth plus 2 J cubed plus J squared]
parts: Name this quantity, denoted B. Solving the Schrodinger equation for a diatomic molecule gives energy levels proportional to this quantity [pause], times J [pause], times J plus 1.
Rotational constants arise when analyzing a molecule using this form of spectroscopy, which uses low energy radiation to analyze rotational transitions.

The expression for the energy levels of a rigid rotor can be made more accurate by adding a "centrifugal distortion" term, which is proportional to this function of J, where J is the angular momentum quantum number.
answers_formatted: J squared, times J plus one squared [accept J to the fourth plus 2 J cubed plus J squared]
acceptable: J squared, times J plus one squared
J squared, times J plus one squared
J to the fourth plus 2 J cubed plus J squared

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about taverns in early American history, for 10 points each.
answers: Lord Dunmore [or John Murray, 4th Earl of Dunmore]
parts: This tavern in Boston, where the first Masonic Lodge was founded, was the birthplace of the Ohio Company and a favorite hangout of Paul Revere. It became infamous as the premier spot to buy slaves in Boston, which led its namesake fruit symbol to become a rallying cry for abolitionism.

This widowed wife of John Timberlake became infamous for telling jokes at taverns across Washington D.C., but is more infamous for causing the Petticoat Affair by marrying Andrew Jackson’s Secretary of War.

The Apollo Room at the Raleigh Tavern became the site of secret meetings to oppose this last royal governor of Virginia, who issued a proclamation in 1775 promising freedom for slaves that fought for the Crown.

bonuses.leadin: Near the end of a novel, Oscar Dowler interrupts this man’s romantic evening with Oscar’s wife Hettie, and threatens to sue him for “alienation of affection.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this character, who ends the novel he titles by becoming executive secretary of the National Association for the Purification of Art and the Press.
Elmer Gantry becomes a preacher in this fictional town of Winnemac, which is also the setting of Sinclair Lewis’s Babbitt.

Gantry’s schemes include using a stenographer to get William Dollinger Styles, the richest man in Zenith, away from the congregation of this man who is later beaten by Fundamentalist Christians for espousing agnosticism.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about dependency theory, for 10 points each.
parts: The theory is often traced to two papers by Hans Singer and this economist, who wrote The Economic Development of Latin America and its Principal Problems. His hypothesis with Singer states that the price of primary goods declines over the long run compared to manufactured goods.
The basic model of dependency theory holds that resources flow from poor, underdeveloped states—known as this region—to countries in the “core” or center region.

This thinker from Guyana, who documented some riots named for him in Kingston, Jamaica in his book The Groundlings with my Brothers, is best remembered for his 1972 book How Europe Underdeveloped Africa.

bonuses.leadin: The kinematics of these events can be depicted graphically on a Dalitz plot. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these events. They're not resonances, but the cross section of these events can is expressed in terms of energy and their namesake "width" by the Breit-Wigner formula.

For a particle that can undergo various decay routes, this quantity is the ratio of the decay width for an individual decay route to the total decay width for all decay routes, or the fraction of particles which will decay by a given route.
The capital form of this letter represents the decay width. Its lowercase form denotes the Lorentz factor.

bonuses.leadin: Music critic Eduard Hanslick. What a dumbass. For 10 points each:
parts: Hanslick claimed that since Franz Liszt was “incapable of creating the beautiful by his own means, he deliberately buil[t] up the hideous” in writing about the first of these “waltzes,” which depicts a “Dance in the Village Inn.”

Hanslick described this Rimsky-Korsakov tone poem as “Mendelssohn’s elves, Gade’s mermaids, Berlioz’s Walpurgis Night, and Wagner’s Venusberg” “boiling” “in a Russian brandy kettle.” Rimsky-Korsakov later adapted this piece into an opera of the same name, which ends with the transformation of Volkhova.

Those Hanslick screeds are included in this Nicolas Slonimsky-edited tome, subtitled “Critical Assaults on Composers Since Beethoven's Time.” It opens with the essay “Non-Acceptance of the Unfamiliar.”

bonuses.leadin: A sadistic group known as The Affront attempts to use this object for war, though it vanishes after a sentient ship called the Secret Service sends a copy of the ship’s personality to this object. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this gigantic spherical black-body that travels across universes. This sentient being casts judgment on whether the life it encounters is ready for Enlightenment in the novel named for it.
The Excession is one of several novels that feature this anarcho-utopian interstellar society. The Gzilt civilization chooses not to join it in the novel The Hydrogen Sonata.
Iain Banks introduced the Culture in a novel whose title “Considers” this man. This man is a sailor who is a “fortnight dead” in T. S. Eliot’s poem “The Waste Land.”

bonuses.leadin: Technically, if a Jewish woman's husband is missing during the course of war, she will have this status until his body is found. For 10 points each:
answers: Saul Lieberman [or Shaul Liberman or the Lieberman clause]
parts: Give this term for a Jewish woman who is literally "anchored" to her marriage. If this type of person remarries, her future children will be considered a mamzer, a kind of bastard.
This document, which a Jewish husband acquires to facilitate a divorce, will prevent a Jewish woman from becoming an agunah. Husbands often prepare one before fighting in a conflict.
The problem of a woman becoming an agunah is often avoided by signing a ketuvah including a clause named for this Conservative Jewish rabbi, which mandates a court will adjudicate the divorce.

bonuses.leadin: 5 years after this brouhaha, its central actor started writing novels like A Parliamentary Affair and The Ambassador. For 10 points each:
answers: salmonella in eggs controversy [accept equivalents mentioning Edwina Currie's claim that most of the eggs in the U.K. are infected with salmonella]
parts: Name or describe this controversy, which resulted in a 60% drop of a certain food item. It led to the resignation of the Junior Health Minister Edwina Currie.

Edwina Currie poured a glass of orange juice over Peter Snape in this election year, the last win for the Conservatives before 2015. Queen Elizabeth II called this year an annus horribilis for the Royal Family.

Edwina Currie’s diaries are better-known for candid descriptions of her affair with this politician, who launched the “Back to Basics” campaign to promote “neighbourliness, decency, and courtesy.” He succeeded Thatcher as PM.
answers_formatted: salmonella in eggs controversy [accept equivalents mentioning Edwina Currie's claim that most of the eggs in the U.K. are infected with salmonella]
acceptable: equivalents mentioning Edwina Currie's claim that most of the eggs in the U.K. are infected with salmonella

bonuses.leadin: The Thellier laws established the “linearity,” “reciprocity,” “independence,” and “additivity” of the “partial” forms of this process, allowing them to be summed to calculate the “total” form of it. For 10 points each:
answers: meteor impacts [accept equivalents mentioning meteors hitting Earth]
parts: Identify this process by which rocks acquire a hysteresis caused by Earth’s magnetic field during the period in which igneous rocks are heated above the Curie temperature, but have not yet solidified.
The thermoremanent magnetization of igneous rocks forms the basis of a technique that allows for the dating of these layers, which are usually comprised of sedimentary rocks.

A less common form of remanent of magnetization used in geological dating is shock-remanent magnetization, which are induced by these events. The range over which these events deposit material is called a strewnfield.

bonuses.leadin: This novel follows a woman who repeatedly drinks glasses of Manzanilla at a bar where a man mysteriously murdered his lover. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel which climaxes with Anne returning to her house drunk and telling her "lover of death" "I already am [dead]." Its title is a reference to the piano piece played by Anne's son, "The Boy."
Moderato Cantabile is a novella by this writer, whose other books include the The Lover.
Duras also wrote the screenplay to this Alain Resnais film, which centers on the conversation between "Her" and "Him," an actress and a Japanese architect.
